material.mattext: A heuristic and an algorithmic solution require the same type of problem solving to develop a step by step solution to a problem.
Identifying the problem is the first step in problem solving.
Defining the knowledge base is part of understanding the problem.
The result of a problem is a set of step by step instructions.
All problems can be solved by writing a set of step by step instructions for a computer.
It is not important to evaluate a solution.
The more alternative solutions that are identified, the better chance you have of a good solution.
Any solution should be considered when solving a problem.
You can find a step-by-step solution for any problem as long as you understand the problem.
Problems that require a heuristic solution cannot be solved through a set of step by step instructions.
Step 3 in problem solving is to identify alternative ways to solve the problem. This means:
To define the knowledge base of all participants.
To write a list of pros and cons for each solution.
To identify as many solutions as possible to the problem.
To identify a few solutions to the problem.
The last step in problem solving is to evaluate the solution. This means:
To check if the knowledge base for errors.
To check if the set of step by step instructions developed in step 5, list instructions that enable you to solve the problem, solve the problem identified in step 1.
To check is the solution solves a problem.
To test for understanding of the identified problem.
A solution that can not be reached through a set of step by step instructions.
The set of step by step instructions to solve the problem.
The knowledge base of a solution.
Step 4 is to select the best way to solve the problem. This means:
To specify pros and cons of each valid solution.
Select one solution after weighing the pros and cons.
A problem that requires a heuristic solution might be:
Choosing stock on the stock market.
Numerical data includes all integer numbers and all real numbers.
Character data includes all numerical data.
True (T, y, or yes) and False (F, n, or no) are the only values in the logical data set.
An equation and an expression are the same thing.
A function is a set of instructions to input data into the computer.
The hierarchy of operations identifies the order in which the operators are executed.
The NOT operator reverses the operand.
The = sign is an operator as well as part of an assignment statement.
A parameter is the data required to process an assignment statement.
Is stored in a named memory location.
Can be changed while a solution is being executed.
Is given a specific data type.
Can be used to calculate expressions.
Does not use quotes around the characters.
In the following expression, what is the order of execution of the operators and the result, given A = 4, B = 5, E = 3, G = True, F = True? A * B + 7 > E ^ 3 OR NOT G AND F
^, *, +, >, NOT, AND, OR : Result is True
^, *, +, >, NOT, AND, OR : Result is False
Evaluate the following equation for R, given A = 4, B = 5, C = 8 is: R = A + B * 2 (C + 4) / A
In the equation: R = A + B * 2 (C + 4) / A, the operands are:
UML (Unified Modeling Language) is a basic tool when using Object Oriented Programming structure.
The problem analysis chart is used to glean needed information and data from a problem.
An Interactivity chart shows the order that the instructions are executed.
A flowchart is a graphical representation of an algorithm.
Internal documentation is written for the user of the program.
Syntax refers to how many errors are found in a solution.
Debugging refers to the process of finding and correcting the errors in a solution.
A module is a set of instructions that processes a subtask of a solution.
The Control Module is a subtask of the Print Module.
Instructions in an algorithm must be complete and be executed one step at a time.
A moth on the computer screen.
A parallelogram in a flowchart represents:
The start or end of the solution.
The computer jumps to the module, executes the instructions in the module, and then quits.
The computer jumps to the module, executes the instructions in the module, and then returns to the next executable instruction.
The computer jumps to the module, executes the instructions in the module, and then jumps to another module according to the structure chart.
The computer ignores the module and returns later to execute the instructions.
Are the finished sets of programming instructions as written in a specific computer language.
Is the set of step by step instructions divided into the specific parts, or modules.
Are the words written inside the flowchart.
Are the modules outlined in a data flow pattern.
Shows the input, the processing, the output, and the module numbers.
Information is from the structure chart and the program analysis chart.
Shows which module each processing step is found.
A set of step-by-step instructions is processed:
In the order they are presented and processed.
Can skip around to other instructions.
Can return to a previously processed instruction.
The set of step-by-step instructions written for the solution to a problem must:
Be within the knowledge base of the problem.
Can use any instruction, regardless of the user or the machine.
Does not have to be in order of processing.
To identify the best alternative solutions you should:
Use other peoples ideas as well as your own.
Use any solution, no matter how unacceptable it is.
Identify only the first few that you think about.
When writing a set of instructions for the computer:
The instructions must be in proper order.
The instructions assume the computer knows nothing.
A problem that would require an algorithmic solution is:
